output.conclusion: By completing this course, you'll have a foundational understanding of time series analysis, enabling you to explore more advanced topics and apply these techniques to real-world problems.
output.introduction: Welcome to the Introduction to Time Series Analysis course! This course is designed for beginners with little to no prior experience in time series analysis. We will cover the fundamental concepts and techniques used to analyze and forecast time series data.

chapters.description: Definition of time series data, examples of time series data in various fields (finance, weather, sales), key characteristics of time series data (trend, seasonality, cyclicality, irregularity).
Understanding trend, seasonality, cyclicality, and irregular components. Visualizing these components in time series plots. Decomposing a time series into its components (brief overview).
Creating time series plots using common tools. Interpreting patterns and trends from time series plots. Identifying outliers and anomalies in time series data.
What is forecasting and why is it important? Different types of forecasting methods (qualitative vs. quantitative). Evaluating forecast accuracy (brief overview).
Calculating simple moving averages. Understanding the effect of window size on smoothing. Limitations of moving averages.
Introduction to exponential smoothing methods (simple, double, triple). Understanding the smoothing parameters (alpha, beta, gamma). Applying exponential smoothing to forecast time series data.
Understanding the concept of stationarity in time series. Why stationarity is important for modeling. Visual inspection of stationarity.
Understanding autocorrelation and partial autocorrelation functions (ACF and PACF). Interpreting ACF and PACF plots to identify patterns in time series data.
Overview of ARIMA models (Autoregressive Integrated Moving Average). Understanding the parameters of ARIMA models (p, d, q). A brief example of using ARIMA for forecasting.

modules.moduleTitle: Introduction to Stationarity and ARIMA Models
